Introduction

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is a chronic idiopathic autoinflammatory condition that primarily involves the joints.  The diagnosis comprises systemic, polyarticular, and oligoarticular subtypes, each with its own clinical presentation, prognosis, and management strategy.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



The pathogenesis of JIA involves complex interactions between the environment and the immune system in genetically susceptible individuals.  For most patients, genetic susceptibility is determined by major histocompatibility complex loci.  These loci contain genes that encode human leukocyte antigen (HLA) proteins.  These proteins present antigenic peptides to T cells for identification of self versus non-self.  Environmental exposures (eg, infections, antibiotic use) can elicit an autoimmune response in genetically susceptible individuals (ie, those with certain HLA gene alleles), affecting the following:



  • Synovium (ie, connective tissue lining the joint capsule):  Inflammatory cells (eg, lymphocytes, plasma cells, macrophages) infiltrate the synovium, resulting in tumor-like tissue proliferation (ie, pannus formation) and fluid accumulation that manifests clinically as joint swelling and deformity.
  • Cartilage:  Inflammatory cells release enzymes that erode and weaken articular cartilage.
  • Bone:  Inflammatory cells release cytokines that activate osteoclasts, resulting in bony erosion.

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation of JIA varies, depending on the subtype (

).  In all subtypes, arthritis presents with joint stiffness, pain, swelling, and warmth, but erythema is not common.  Patients often have a limp in the morning that improves throughout the day and have no history of trauma.

Systemic JIA (10% of cases)



  • Age:  Although systemic JIA can present at any age (if age >16, referred to as adult-onset Still disease), peak incidence occurs at age 1-5.
  • Arthritis:  The arthritis involves â‰¥1 joint within 6 months of symptom onset.  Any joint can be affected, but the wrists, knees, and ankles are most commonly involved.  Arthritis typically presents after the systemic symptoms (eg, fever, rash) but may be preceded by arthralgia.
  • Systemic symptoms:
    • Quotidian fever (ie, 1-2 spikes per day):  Temperatures reach â‰¥39 C (102.2 F), often in the evening, for â‰¥2 weeks.  They return to normal or below normal between spikes.
    • Rash:  An evanescent, salmon-colored, macular rash typically appears on the trunk and proximal extremities and accompanies fever spikes.  The rash fades as the temperature returns to normal.


Patients often develop lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly.  Various forms of serositis (eg, pericarditis, pleuritis, peritonitis) can occur; although rare, large pericardial effusions that result in cardiac tamponade can also develop.  Systemic JIA affects male and females equally.

Polyarticular JIA (40% of cases)



  • Age:  Peak incidence is bimodal, occurring at age 2-5 and 10-14.
  • Joints:
    • 2-5 years:  Arthritis initially involves 1-2 joints but rapidly progresses to â‰¥5 joints within 6 months of symptom onset; disease progression often follows a viral infection.  Arthritis is symmetrical, and like in systemic JIA, the wrists, knees, and ankles are most commonly affected.
    • 10-14 years:  Arthritis involves â‰¥5 joints within 5 months of symptom onset, often including small joints of the hands and feet.  Arthritis is symmetrical.


  • Systemic symptoms (eg, fever, rash):  These symptoms are absent, although complications involving other systems (eg, uveitis) can occur.


Polyarticular JIA affects more female than males.

Oligoarticular JIA (50% of cases)



  • Age:  Peak incidence occurs at age 1-3; presentation after age 5 is rare.
  • Joints:  Arthritis involves <5 joints within 6 months of symptom onset and can be asymmetric, unlike polyarticular JIA.  The knees and ankles are most commonly affected.
  • Systemic symptoms (eg, fever, rash):  Systemic symptoms are absent, although complications involving other systems (eg, uveitis) may occur.


Like polyarticular JIA, oligoarticular JIA affects more female than males.

Diagnosis



JIA is a clinical diagnosis, supported by laboratory and imaging studies.

History and physical examination



Diagnosis requires a detailed history and physical examination, including a thorough assessment of joint involvement and systemic symptoms (eg, fever, rash).

Laboratory evaluation



  • Complete blood count:  Hemoglobin (due to chronic inflammation) is decreased, platelets are increased, and leukocytes are increased (can be normal in oligoarticular JIA)
  • Inflammatory markers:  Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is increased, as is C-reactive protein (can be normal in oligoarticular JIA).
  • Autoantibodies: The presence of autoantibodies varies, depending on the subtype, as follows:
    • Systemic JIA:  Antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) and rheumatoid factor (RF) are typically negative.
    • Polyarticular JIA:  The ANA level is often positive in younger patients (age 2-5) and is associated with uveitis.  RF can be positive in older patients (age 10-14), and when present, the clinical course is similar to that of rheumatoid arthritis in adults.
    • Oligoarticular JIA:  ANAs are often positive and associated with uveitis, like in polyarticular JIA.

Imaging



  • X-rays reveal joint space narrowing and bony erosions (
    image 1
    ).
  • Ultrasonography detects synovitis and effusions, which guides joint aspiration.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for JIA includes other etiologies of nontraumatic joint swelling, including infectious, inflammatory/rheumatologic, and neoplastic conditions.  Key distinguishing features between JIA and these other diagnoses include (

):



  • Infectious arthritis:  presents acutely with persistent fever and progressive joint pain and swelling that often prevent ambulation.  Typically, only 1 joint is affected.  Like in JIA, laboratory findings include leukocytosis and thrombocytosis (due to inflammation), but anemia is not common in this acute condition.
  • Inflammatory/rheumatologic arthritis:  transient synovitis typically presents in young patients with acute pain and restricted range of motion of the hip joint following a viral illness.  Fever and rash are uncommon, and inflammatory markers are normal or only mildly elevated.  In addition, acute rheumatic fever can cause rash and transient, migratory arthritis following a group A Streptococcus infection.
  • Neoplasms (eg, acute lymphoblastic leukemia):  can present with subacute or chronic systemic symptoms (eg, fever) and joint pain that can affect multiple joints.  Unlike in JIA, the joint pain is severe and worse at night, often preventing ambulation.  Leukopenia and thrombocytopenia are also common.

Management



The goal of JIA management is to preserve joint function by minimizing inflammation.  Strategies include:

Nonpharmacologic management



Nonpharmacologic treatment option includes physical therapy and occupational therapy to maintain mobility and function.

Pharmacologic management



Pharmacologic management includes nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) (eg, naproxen) for first-line treatment of pain and inflammation.  Glucocorticoids and disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs), including biologic and nonbiologic agents, may be considered in severe or refractory cases.  Although they are effective, long-term glucocorticoid use should be limited due to unfavorable adverse effects (eg, osteoporosis).  In most cases, glucocorticoids are used initially, followed by DMARDs (eg, methotrexate) or biologic agents.



Methotrexate is a folate antagonist that competitively inhibits dihydrofolate reductase (

figure 1
), an enzyme that synthesizes nucleic acid precursors for DNA synthesis and repair.  Methotrexate preferentially inhibits the growth of rapidly dividing cells; however, other tissues with rapidly dividing cells are also affected, causing significant adverse effects, including ulcerations (oral and gastrointestinal mucosa), alopecia, and pancytopenia.  Methotrexate can also cause hepatotoxicity and pulmonary fibrosis.  Therefore, patients require serial laboratory evaluations (eg, complete blood count, aminotransferases, creatinine) to monitor for toxicity.



Patients should also be monitored for complications that often require alternate management strategies.

Complications

Systemic JIA



  • Macrophage activation syndrome (MAS):  MAS is a hemophagocytic syndrome characterized by unregulated activation of macrophages and lymphocytes that can occur at any time, although this occurring in the first few weeks of illness is most common.  Patients often have unremitting fever and rash, unlike the intermittent fever and rash seen in systemic JIA.  Other findings may include spontaneous bleeding, liver dysfunction, and lethargy.  Laboratory findings include declining white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count (from elevated levels seen in systemic JIA) with markedly elevated liver enzymes and ferritin.  Patients require more aggressive treatment of the underlying JIA, often including a course of high-dose glucocorticoids.
  • Lung disease:  Chronic parenchymal lung disease characterized by alveolar proteinosis and interstitial lung disease occurs in severe cases of JIA, particularly those treated with biologic DMARDs.  Patients typically have acute erythematous clubbing and mild respiratory symptoms (eg, tachypnea) but no overt respiratory distress.
  • Abnormal growth:  Various growth abnormalities, including short stature, obesity, and failure to thrive, can occur, particularly in patients with prolonged glucocorticoid use.

Polyarticular JIA



  • Temporomandibular joint (TMJ) arthritis:  TMJ arthritis can be asymptomatic and lead to micrognathia that requires surgical correction.
  • Uveitis (eg, intraocular inflammation):  Uveitis is asymptomatic, and routine screening is required to prevent irreversible vision loss.  Patients with ANAs are more likely to develop uveitis.

Oligoarticular JIA



  • Uveitis:  This is the most common complication.
  • Other complications:  TMJ arthritis, leg-length discrepancy (when a unilateral knee joint is involved), and short stature are less common complications of oligoarticular JIA.


In addition, all patients are at increased risk for anemia due to chronic inflammation.  Anemia can be exacerbated by NSAID-induced gastritis with chronic gastrointestinal bleeding.

Prognosis



The prognosis of JIA depends on the subtype and the response to treatment.  In general, patients with systemic JIA have the least favorable prognosis, and patients with oligoarticular JIA have the most favorable.  Among all subtypes, poor response to therapy is a predictor of significant morbidity, including destructive arthritis and disability.

Summary



Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) (
